div.head: Civil War Letter 1861
div.p: This morning when about to go into the country to visit your cousin Robert who still continues in a very distressing situation, I recieved your letter, in which you expressed a desire to go to Pensacola.

I requested your brother Sterling to write to you, as it was out of my power. I hope you will recieve his letter & be satisfied that, so far from reflecting any discredit on you to stay, it is not in your power to go, as the only a limited number can go.

If you had an opportunity to
go, it would prove of no benefit or credit to you, as it is not at all probable there will be any war. If the company go any farther than Macon, it is not likely they will remain long in Pensecola; and while there they will be exposed to a sickly climate, mosquitoes sandflies & various annoyances.
At this time it will be is all important that your education should not be interupted, for time lost now can never be regained.

I hope you will now make up your mind to remain contentedly at college & not think about leaving, when so much evil & no benefit would be likely to result from going, even if you had the oppor
tunity. I regret very much that Sterling has to go & would prevent it, if I could consistanly; but under the circumstances, it appears to be unavoidable.

You can sertainly derive more benefit from college than from spending the time in Macon, one of the most immoral & dissapated places in the or Southern Confederacy, in company it is true with many who are gentlemen, some christian gentlemen, but a large portion of whom are the of the town & country, who leave their homes more for the good of their homes than of the place to which they go.

I trust my dearest Robert, you will be contented to remain where you are. You know we have no motives but your
good. We wish you to do what will most to your benefit & happiness.
I know you love us & have always evinced a disposition to obey and please us; & you can not doubt our regard for you.
Write us immediatly. I must close in hard, lest I may be too late for the mail. Your mother & all join me in most devoted love to you.
